For more than a century, cars have been a symbol of engineering prowess because of their hardware: engines, transmissions, brakes, axles, and other physical parts. Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.  

The notion of a connected car has been evolving for decades. Emergency-based communications systems that allow drivers to call for help with the push of a button have been around for 30 years. Gradually more software has been implemented to control the hardware and driving experience — and more compute power, data, and AI has enabled everything from GPS routing to crash avoidance to autonomous driving. 

Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle, where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.

Some cars, especially the tech-forward EVs, are a harbinger of the dominant role software will play in the automotive equation going forward. But cars that park themselves, offer guidance to the nearest gas or charging station, signal needed repairs, or pull up a child’s favorite shows — these won’t be nice-to-have, premium features in the future, they’ll come standard on every vehicle. And the key to enabling these experiences is the hundreds of onboard sensors and vast amounts of data coming from the car.

A ‘seismic shift’ in the auto industry
Within the walls of Salesforce, there’s nobody who can speak to these data-driven, connected car experiences better than Achyut Jajoo. Though he’s now the company’s SVP and GM of Automotive and Manufacturing, Jajoo started his career as an engineer in Detroit, designing cars and trucks.

“A lot of people don’t fully understand how seismic a shift the auto industry is going through today. We hear about the death of gas vehicles and the electric revolution, but the biggest transformation is a reimagining of the underlying architecture of what makes a car. Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially,” according to Jajoo.

Indeed, he said, the connected car will connect drivers, manufacturers, dealers, and auto lenders in ways that create more personalized experiences and higher levels of customer service.

Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially.

ACHYUT JAJOO, SVP AND GM, AUTOMOTIVE AND MANUFACTURING 
For one, cars will no longer be limited to the features and upgrades selected at a dealership. While some of the more advanced EVs have already started down this path, soon many more cars and trucks will be dynamic, instantly-upgradable machines thanks to the software, connectivity, and volumes of telemetry data that a car generates. 

“So now in real time, the data that is coming from the car can help shape the features and change the way you’re experiencing the car itself,” Jajoo said. 

For example, a car manufacturer may receive real-time telemetry data that one of their vehicles has started a road trip, but the driver doesn’t have trip optimization service installed. To help, they immediately send a notification through the car’s infotainment system to install the service. Now, the car’s software can show the driver the best rest stops, where to recharge or refuel at the lowest cost, and other features that will make the trip easier and more enjoyable.

Durante más de un siglo, los automóviles han sido un símbolo de destreza de ingeniería debido a su hardware: motores, transmisiones, frenos, ejes y otras partes físicas. Ahora, sin embargo, hemos ingresado a la era del vehículo definido por software donde el software, no el hardware, da forma a la experiencia de conducción.

La noción de un automóvil conectado ha evolucionado durante décadas. Los sistemas de comunicaciones basados ​​en emergencias que permiten a los conductores solicitar ayuda con la presentación de un botón han existido durante 30 años. Poco a poco, se ha implementado más software para controlar la experiencia de hardware y conducción, y más potencia de cálculo, datos, y la IA ha permitido todo, desde el enrutamiento GPS hasta la evitación de bloqueo hasta la conducción autónoma.

Ahora, sin embargo, hemos ingresado a la era del vehículo definido por software, donde el software, no el hardware, da forma a la experiencia de conducción.

Algunos autos, especialmente los EV de la tecnología, son un presagio del que jugará el software dominante en la ecuación automotriz en el futuro. Pero los automóviles que se estacionan, ofrecen orientación a la estación de gas o carga más cercana, la señal necesaria para las reparaciones o extrae los programas favoritos de un niño: estas no serán agradables y primas en el futuro, vendrán de manera estándar. en cada vehículo. Y la clave para habilitar estas experiencias son los cientos de sensores a bordo y grandes cantidades de datos provenientes del automóvil.

Un "cambio sísmico" en la industria automotriz
Dentro de las paredes de Salesforce, no hay nadie que pueda hablar con estas experiencias de automóviles conectados y basados ​​en datos mejor que Achyut Jajoo. Aunque ahora es el SVP y GM de Automotriz y Manufactura de la compañía, Jazoo comenzó su carrera como ingeniero en Detroit, diseñando automóviles y camiones.

"Mucha gente no entiende completamente cuán sísmica está pasando la industria automotriz hoy. Escuchamos sobre la muerte de los vehículos de gas y la revolución eléctrica, pero la mayor transformación es una reinvención de la arquitectura subyacente de lo que hace un automóvil. Una vez que todos los automóviles, eléctricos, híbridos o de gas, están más definidos por software y conectados, las capacidades y posibilidades de experiencias de manejo más agradables, seguras y sostenibles crecerán exponencialmente ", según JAJOO.

De hecho, dijo, el automóvil conectado conectará a los conductores, fabricantes, distribuidores y prestamistas de automóviles de manera que cree experiencias más personalizadas y niveles más altos de servicio al cliente.

Una vez que todos los automóviles, eléctricos, híbridos o de gas, están más definidos por software y conectados, las capacidades y posibilidades para experiencias de manejo más agradables, seguras y sostenibles crecerán exponencialmente.

Achyut Jazoo, SVP y GM, Automotive and Manufacturing
Por un lado, los automóviles ya no se limitarán a las características y actualizaciones seleccionadas en un concesionario. Si bien algunos de los EV más avanzados ya han comenzado en este camino, pronto muchos más automóviles y camiones serán máquinas dinámicas y actualizables al instante gracias al software, la conectividad y los volúmenes de datos de telemetría que genera un automóvil.

"Entonces, ahora en tiempo real, los datos que provienen del automóvil pueden ayudar a dar forma a las características y cambiar la forma en que está experimentando el automóvil en sí", dijo Jajoo.

Por ejemplo, un fabricante de automóviles puede recibir datos de telemetría en tiempo real que uno de sus vehículos ha comenzado un viaje por carretera, pero el conductor no tiene instalado el servicio de optimización de viaje. Para ayudar, envían inmediatamente una notificación a través del sistema de información y entretenimiento del automóvil para instalar el servicio. Ahora, el software del automóvil puede mostrar al conductor las mejores paradas de descanso, dónde recargar o repostar al menor costo y otras características que harán que el viaje sea más fácil y más agradable.

I mer än ett sekel har bilar varit en symbol för teknisk förmåga på grund av deras hårdvara: motorer, växellådor, bromsar, axlar och andra fysiska delar. Nu har vi emellertid gått in i eran för det mjukvarudefinierade fordonet där programvara, inte hårdvara, formar körupplevelsen.

Uppfattningen om en ansluten bil har utvecklats i årtionden. Nödbaserade kommunikationssystem som gör det möjligt för förare att ringa efter hjälp med en knapptryckning har funnits i 30 år. Gradvis har mer programvara implementerats för att kontrollera hårdvaru- och körupplevelsen - och mer datorkraft, data och AI har gjort det möjligt för allt från GPS -routing att krascha undvikande till autonom körning.

Nu har vi emellertid gått in i eran för det mjukvarudefinierade fordonet, där programvara, inte hårdvara, formar körupplevelsen.

Vissa bilar, särskilt de tekniska Forward EVs, är en föregångare av den dominerande rollprogramvaran kommer att spela i bilekvationen framöver. Men bilar som parkerar sig själva, erbjuder vägledning till närmaste gas- eller laddningsstation, signal behövs reparationer eller drar upp ett barns favoritprogram-dessa kommer inte att vara trevliga att ha, premiumfunktioner i framtiden, de kommer standard på varje fordon. Och nyckeln till att möjliggöra dessa upplevelser är hundratals ombordssensorer och stora mängder data som kommer från bilen.

En "seismisk förändring" i bilindustrin
Inom väggarna i Salesforce finns det ingen som kan prata med dessa datadrivna, anslutna bilupplevelser bättre än Achyut Jajoo. Även om han nu är företagets SVP och GM för bil och tillverkning, började Jajoo sin karriär som ingenjör i Detroit och designade bilar och lastbilar.

”Många människor förstår inte helt hur seismisk en förändring bilindustrin går igenom idag. Vi hör om döden av gasfordon och den elektriska revolutionen, men den största omvandlingen är en återintegrering av den underliggande arkitekturen för vad som gör en bil. När alla bilar-elektriska, hybrid eller gas-är mer mjukvarudefinierade och anslutna, kommer kapaciteten och möjligheterna för roligare, säkra och hållbara körupplevelser att växa exponentiellt, ”enligt Jajoo.

I själva verket, sade han, kommer den anslutna bilen att ansluta förare, tillverkare, återförsäljare och bilförlånare på sätt som skapar mer personliga upplevelser och högre nivåer av kundservice.

När alla bilar-elektriska, hybrid eller gas-är mer mjukvarudefinierade och anslutna kommer kapaciteten och möjligheterna för roligare, säkra och hållbara körupplevelser att växa exponentiellt.

Achyut Jajoo, SVP och GM, Automotive and Manufacturing
För det första kommer bilar inte längre att begränsas till de funktioner och uppgraderingar som valts till en återförsäljare. Medan några av de mer avancerade EV: erna redan har börjat på denna väg, kommer snart många fler bilar och lastbilar att vara dynamiska, omedelbart uppgraderade maskiner tack vare programvaran, anslutningen och volymerna av telemetri-data som en bil genererar.

"Så nu i realtid kan de data som kommer från bilen hjälpa till att forma funktionerna och ändra hur du upplever själva bilen," sade Jajoo.

Till exempel kan en biltillverkare få telemetri-data i realtid som ett av deras fordon har startat en bilresa, men föraren har inte resoptimeringstjänst installerad. För att hjälpa skickar de omedelbart ett meddelande via bilens infotainment -system för att installera tjänsten. Nu kan bilens programvara visa föraren de bästa vilostoppen, var man ska ladda eller tanka till lägsta kostnad och andra funktioner som gör resan enklare och roligare.

一個多世紀以來，汽車一直是工程能力的象徵，因為它們的硬件：發動機，變速器，制動器，車軸和其他物理部件。但是，現在，我們進入了軟件定義的車輛的時代，軟件而不是硬件可以塑造駕駛體驗。

連接汽車的概念已經發展了數十年。允許駕駛員在按鈕時尋求幫助的緊急通信系統已經存在了30年。逐漸實施了更多的軟件來控制硬件和駕駛體驗 - 更多的計算功率，數據和AI使從GPS路由到避免崩潰到自動駕駛的所有內容。

但是，現在，我們進入了軟件定義的車輛時代，在這裡，軟件而不是硬件可以塑造駕駛體驗。

一些汽車，尤其是技術前進的電動汽車，是在汽車方程中扮演的主要角色軟件的預兆。但是自行停車的汽車，為最近的汽油或充電站提供指導，信號需要維修或拉起孩子最喜歡的節目 - 這些節目將來不會是不錯的優質功能，它們將成為標準的標準在每輛車上。實現這些體驗的關鍵是車載傳感器和大量來自汽車的數據。

汽車行業的“地震轉變”
在Salesforce的牆壁內，沒有人能比Achyut Jajoo更好地與這些數據驅動的，連接的汽車體驗交談。儘管他現在是該公司的汽車和製造業總經理，但Jajoo開始了他在底特律的工程師的職業生涯，設計了汽車和卡車。

“很多人都不完全了解汽車行業今天正在發生的地震轉變。我們聽說了汽油汽車和電動革命的死亡，但最大的轉變是對製造汽車的基礎建築的重新構想。一旦所有汽車（電動，混合或天然氣）都是更明確的和連接的，那麼更愉快，安全和可持續的駕駛體驗的功能和可能性將成倍增長，” Jajoo說。

他說，實際上，連接的汽車將以創造更多個性化體驗和更高水平的客戶服務的方式將驅動程序，製造商，經銷商和汽車貸方連接起來。

一旦所有汽車（電動，混合或天然氣）都更加定義和連接，那麼更愉快，安全和可持續的駕駛體驗的功能和可能性將成倍增長。

Achyut Jajoo，高級副總裁和通用汽車，汽車和製造業
首先，汽車將不再僅限於經銷商選擇的功能和升級。儘管一些更高級的電動汽車已經開始沿著這條路開始，但由於汽車生成的軟件，連接性和遙測數據，很快，更多的汽車和卡車將是動態的，可立即升級的機器。

Jajoo說：“因此，現在是實時的，來自汽車的數據可以幫助塑造功能，並改變您體驗您的汽車本身的方式。”

例如，汽車製造商可能會收到他們的一輛汽車開始公路旅行的實時遙測數據，但駕駛員沒有安裝旅行優化服務。為了提供幫助，他們立即通過汽車的信息娛樂系統發送通知以安裝服務。現在，汽車的軟件可以向駕駛員展示最佳的休息站，以最低的成本充電或加油，以及其他功能，這些功能將使旅行更輕鬆，更愉快。

Por um lado, os carros não serão mais limitados aos recursos e atualizações selecionadas em uma concessionária. Embora alguns dos VEs mais avançados já tenham iniciado esse caminho, em breve muitos outros carros e caminhões serão máquinas dinâmicas e instantaneamente atualizáveis, graças ao software, conectividade e volumes de dados de telemetria que um carro gera.

For more than a century, cars have been a symbol of engineering prowess because of their hardware: engines, transmissions, brakes, axles, and other physical parts. Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.  

The notion of a connected car has been evolving for decades. Emergency-based communications systems that allow drivers to call for help with the push of a button have been around for 30 years. Gradually more software has been implemented to control the hardware and driving experience — and more compute power, data, and AI has enabled everything from GPS routing to crash avoidance to autonomous driving. 

Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle, where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.

Some cars, especially the tech-forward EVs, are a harbinger of the dominant role software will play in the automotive equation going forward. But cars that park themselves, offer guidance to the nearest gas or charging station, signal needed repairs, or pull up a child’s favorite shows — these won’t be nice-to-have, premium features in the future, they’ll come standard on every vehicle. And the key to enabling these experiences is the hundreds of onboard sensors and vast amounts of data coming from the car.

A ‘seismic shift’ in the auto industry
Within the walls of Salesforce, there’s nobody who can speak to these data-driven, connected car experiences better than Achyut Jajoo. Though he’s now the company’s SVP and GM of Automotive and Manufacturing, Jajoo started his career as an engineer in Detroit, designing cars and trucks.

“A lot of people don’t fully understand how seismic a shift the auto industry is going through today. We hear about the death of gas vehicles and the electric revolution, but the biggest transformation is a reimagining of the underlying architecture of what makes a car. Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially,” according to Jajoo.

Indeed, he said, the connected car will connect drivers, manufacturers, dealers, and auto lenders in ways that create more personalized experiences and higher levels of customer service.

Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially.

For one, cars will no longer be limited to the features and upgrades selected at a dealership. While some of the more advanced EVs have already started down this path, soon many more cars and trucks will be dynamic, instantly-upgradable machines thanks to the software, connectivity, and volumes of telemetry data that a car generates. 

“So now in real time, the data that is coming from the car can help shape the features and change the way you’re experiencing the car itself,” Jajoo said. 

For example, a car manufacturer may receive real-time telemetry data that one of their vehicles has started a road trip, but the driver doesn’t have trip optimization service installed. To help, they immediately send a notification through the car’s infotainment system to install the service. Now, the car’s software can show the driver the best rest stops, where to recharge or refuel at the lowest cost, and other features that will make the trip easier and more enjoyable.

For more than a century, cars have been a symbol of engineering prowess because of their hardware: engines, transmissions, brakes, axles, and other physical parts. Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.  

The notion of a connected car has been evolving for decades. Emergency-based communications systems that allow drivers to call for help with the push of a button have been around for 30 years. Gradually more software has been implemented to control the hardware and driving experience — and more compute power, data, and AI has enabled everything from GPS routing to crash avoidance to autonomous driving. 

Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle, where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.

Some cars, especially the tech-forward EVs, are a harbinger of the dominant role software will play in the automotive equation going forward. But cars that park themselves, offer guidance to the nearest gas or charging station, signal needed repairs, or pull up a child’s favorite shows — these won’t be nice-to-have, premium features in the future, they’ll come standard on every vehicle. And the key to enabling these experiences is the hundreds of onboard sensors and vast amounts of data coming from the car.

A ‘seismic shift’ in the auto industry
Within the walls of Salesforce, there’s nobody who can speak to these data-driven, connected car experiences better than Achyut Jajoo. Though he’s now the company’s SVP and GM of Automotive and Manufacturing, Jajoo started his career as an engineer in Detroit, designing cars and trucks.

“A lot of people don’t fully understand how seismic a shift the auto industry is going through today. We hear about the death of gas vehicles and the electric revolution, but the biggest transformation is a reimagining of the underlying architecture of what makes a car. Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially,” according to Jajoo.

Indeed, he said, the connected car will connect drivers, manufacturers, dealers, and auto lenders in ways that create more personalized experiences and higher levels of customer service.

Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially.

For one, cars will no longer be limited to the features and upgrades selected at a dealership. While some of the more advanced EVs have already started down this path, soon many more cars and trucks will be dynamic, instantly-upgradable machines thanks to the software, connectivity, and volumes of telemetry data that a car generates. 

“So now in real time, the data that is coming from the car can help shape the features and change the way you’re experiencing the car itself,” Jajoo said. 

For example, a car manufacturer may receive real-time telemetry data that one of their vehicles has started a road trip, but the driver doesn’t have trip optimization service installed. To help, they immediately send a notification through the car’s infotainment system to install the service. Now, the car’s software can show the driver the best rest stops, where to recharge or refuel at the lowest cost, and other features that will make the trip easier and more enjoyable.

For more than a century, cars have been a symbol of engineering prowess because of their hardware: engines, transmissions, brakes, axles, and other physical parts. Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.  

The notion of a connected car has been evolving for decades. Emergency-based communications systems that allow drivers to call for help with the push of a button have been around for 30 years. Gradually more software has been implemented to control the hardware and driving experience — and more compute power, data, and AI has enabled everything from GPS routing to crash avoidance to autonomous driving. 

Now, however, we’ve entered the era of the software-defined vehicle, where software, not hardware, shapes the driving experience.

Some cars, especially the tech-forward EVs, are a harbinger of the dominant role software will play in the automotive equation going forward. But cars that park themselves, offer guidance to the nearest gas or charging station, signal needed repairs, or pull up a child’s favorite shows — these won’t be nice-to-have, premium features in the future, they’ll come standard on every vehicle. And the key to enabling these experiences is the hundreds of onboard sensors and vast amounts of data coming from the car.

A ‘seismic shift’ in the auto industry
Within the walls of Salesforce, there’s nobody who can speak to these data-driven, connected car experiences better than Achyut Jajoo. Though he’s now the company’s SVP and GM of Automotive and Manufacturing, Jajoo started his career as an engineer in Detroit, designing cars and trucks.

“A lot of people don’t fully understand how seismic a shift the auto industry is going through today. We hear about the death of gas vehicles and the electric revolution, but the biggest transformation is a reimagining of the underlying architecture of what makes a car. Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially,” according to Jajoo.

Indeed, he said, the connected car will connect drivers, manufacturers, dealers, and auto lenders in ways that create more personalized experiences and higher levels of customer service.

Once all cars – electric, hybrid, or gas – are more software-defined and connected, the capabilities and possibilities for more enjoyable, safe, and sustainable driving experiences will grow exponentially.

For one, cars will no longer be limited to the features and upgrades selected at a dealership. While some of the more advanced EVs have already started down this path, soon many more cars and trucks will be dynamic, instantly-upgradable machines thanks to the software, connectivity, and volumes of telemetry data that a car generates. 

“So now in real time, the data that is coming from the car can help shape the features and change the way you’re experiencing the car itself,” Jajoo said. 

For example, a car manufacturer may receive real-time telemetry data that one of their vehicles has started a road trip, but the driver doesn’t have trip optimization service installed. To help, they immediately send a notification through the car’s infotainment system to install the service. Now, the car’s software can show the driver the best rest stops, where to recharge or refuel at the lowest cost, and other features that will make the trip easier and more enjoyable.
